name: Basic Genetics and Research
section_name: Learn about basic genetics and DNA research. Vault
summary:
DNA testing can provide you with some interesting and unexpected clues about your ancestry and ethnicity.

(See the Part 2 video in Goal 2.)

choices.name: Get an introduction to genetics for family history.

hidden.content: • There are 3 different kinds of DNA tests commonly used in genealogy: Y-DNA, mitochondrial, and autosomal.

• Some basic anatomy
  • The double helix
  • Two halves make a whole
  • How to make a match

content.text:

    ☆ FS—DNA testing: What is it, and how can you benefit from it?

  4. Learn the basics of chromosomes and inheritance on the Learn Genetics site at the Univ. of Utah. There is a series of helpful animations and videos on the site.

choices.name: Learn the basics of DNA research for family history.

hidden.content: • DNA research for genealogy can be used to confirm theories or previous research, break a brick wall, find relatives that were adopted, and more.

name: Learn about DNA Testing
summary: This Goal helps you learn about DNA tests for recent ancestry, maternal lines, and paternal lines.

choices.name: Learn the basics of DNA testing.

hidden.content: • DNA tests come in different varieties that each accomplish something different. It's important to know what you are looking to get out of the DNA test before purchasing it.

content.text:
1. Learn about DNA Testing.

    ☆ Y-DNA vs. mtDNA vs. Autosomal DNA - 2018
    ☆ Understanding DNA Testing for Genealogy Research—5:00 - 2014



  2. Get an introduction to different types of DNA tests.

    ☆ FS—DNA: An Introduction to Genetic Genealogy - Types of DNA—15:16 - 2018

  3. Here are "five truths" about DNA testing.

    ☆ 5 Truths about DNA Tests—4:49 - 2016



  4. Learn about the kinds of information that DNA tests provide you.

    ☆ I Took a DNA Test: Now What? - 2017

  5. Review the links in the blog article for FAQs about DNA testing.

    ☆ DNA Testing, Part One

  6. The DearMYRTLE YouTube Channel has a series of videos called "Demystifying DNA Tests".

    ☆ YT—Demystifying DNA Tests

  7. Use these DNA inheritance charts to better understand DNA test results.

    ☆ FL—Charts for Understanding DNA Inheritance - 2019

  8. Learn about STR (Short Tandem Repeats) and SNP (Single Nucleotide Polymorphism) tests for DNA inheritance.

    ☆ WDY—What is STR and SNP DNA?

choices.name: Learn about autosomal (recent ancestry) DNA testing.

hidden.content:
• Autosomal DNA tests are probably the most accessible and popular tests available now.
  • Autosomal tests can be taken by either gender and will provide ethnicity percentages as well as tell you how much DNA you have in common with another person.

content.text:
1. Get an overview of autosomal DNA testing in this video.

    ☆ AC—The Power of Autosomal DNA—7:51 - 2016


    ☆ Autosomal DNA - 2012

  2. Learn more about autosomal DNA in this video.

    ☆ BYU—Autosomal DNA for Genealogy—20:58 - 2014


  3. Learn how to use autosomal DNA research in practice.

    ☆ Autosomal DNA: How to Use It in Practice—56:31 - 2015

  4. Learn about solving brick walls in research with autosomal test results.

    ☆ FL—Autosomal DNA and Solving Brick Walls - 2018

  5. Explore the Autosomal DNA page on the ISOGG website for help resources.

choices.name: Learn about mitochondrial (maternal line) DNA testing.

hidden.content: • Mitochondrial DNA tests are used to trace the direct maternal line and may help you overcome a genealogy brick wall.

content.text:
1. Get an overview of mtDNA testing in this Geni blog article.

    ☆ mtDNA Testing - 2012

  2. Get an overview of mtDNA in this brief video.

    ☆ Mitochondrial DNA—1:04 - 2010



  3. Learn more about mtDNA and what it can tell you about maternal ancestry.

    ☆ Genetic Ancestry Testing: Mitochondrial DNA—4:53 - 2014



  4. Explore the Mitochondrial DNA page on the ISOGG website for help resources.

hidden.content:
• Y-DNA tests are used to trace the direct paternal line and only men can take these tests.
  • Y-DNA is often used when tracing a surname back in time.

content.text:
1. Get an overview of Y-DNA testing in this article.

    ☆ Y Chromosome DNA Test - 2022

  2. Watch these videos to learn more about Y-DNA testing for genealogy.

    ☆ Using Y-DNA to Research your Surname—3:58 - 2018



    ☆ Y-DNA Basics with Q & A—60:23 - 2020



  3. Explore the Y-DNA page on the ISOGG website for help resources.

name: Take a DNA Test and View Results
section_name: Take a DNA test from Living DNA and view results.

choices.name: Take a DNA test from Living DNA.

content.text:
1. Visit the Living DNA site for an overview of DNA testing.
  2. Order and take the Living DNA test. You can read instructions in the DNA kit that arrives or view them online.
  3. Send your DNA sample to Living DNA as instructed. You will be notified by email when the processing is done and you can view results online.
  4. In the upper menu, create an account and sign in to it in order to view the test results.
  5. Open the My Tests screen (the default screen when logged in to Living DNA).
  6. Find your test in the list and click View Test.
  7. To connect your Living DNA account with Findmypast, click My Account (top menu) and follow the instructions in Choice E below.
  8. If you have multiple accounts, you can switch between them in the top menu .

choices.name: See ancestry information for your Living DNA test results.

content.text:
1. In the left pane, click Ancestry. A list is displayed with percentages of your recent ancestry.
  2. Click a location in the list to display a history for that area and to zoom in to the location on the map (right side). When you are finished reading, click "Back to results" (upper left).
  3. On the map, you can click Zoom In or Zoom Out (lower right), or use full-screen mode (upper left).

The Relatives tab displays a list of Living DNA users with whom you share DNA ancestry (your DNA matches). Your predicted relationship and amount of DNA shared with each user is displayed.

  1. If you have not yet opted in to Family Networks,
    a) In the left pane,
    a) click Relatives;
    b) Click Yes, let's go! on two screens;
    c) Read the "Use of your Personal Information" screen;
    d) Click Yes, I Consent on four screens (third screen is optional).
  2. A list of DNA matches is displayed, with username, predicted relationship, and amount of DNA shared (centimorgans) for each match person.
  3. To sort the results, click the Sort by button and select "Relationship degree" (default), "Newest first" or "Alphabetical". For "Relationship degree" you can click the Info button (right side) for each degree section to learn more about the relationship.
  4. To view additional DNA relatives, if any, use the navigation buttons at the bottom of the page.
  5. To send a message to a DNA relative in the list,
    a) Click the person's name;
    b) Type your message in the "Say hello" box; and
    c) Click the Send icon. Messages you have received from others appear above the box. You can also see your messages by clicking the Messaging tab that appears at the bottom of the Family Networks screen.
  6. To block a user from sending you messages, click Block User and then click Yes. To unblock, click Unblock User and then click Yes.
  7. Below the message area you can common relatives you share with the selected DNA relative.
  8. To view the profile for one of your DNA matches, in the left pane click Profiles.

choices.name: Get an introduction to DNA research for adoptees.

hidden.content:
• Taking a DNA test will match you with any people you share DNA with and are also in the database, so adoptees will gain insight as to exactly who they are related to.
  • Have any other known biological members take the DNA test as well. The more samples of your family there are, the more the information the database has to use.
  • Adoption can be a sensitive topic, so try to consult biological families before delving in depth with DNA.

• Prepare to contact
  • Talk to other reunited adoptees or join DNA adoption groups

  2. Get free help with your DNA testing questions from members of the RootsChat forum.
  3. Check out the Genetic Genealogy FamilySearch Community page.
  4. Explore DNA questions and Autosomal DNA questions in the Genealogy Stack Exchange.

name: Manage DNA Accounts, Profiles, and Settings
section_name: Manage DNA accounts, profiles, and settings.
summary: To access these options, first log in to your Living DNA account (DNA in the top menu).

choices.name: Edit your Living DNA profile settings.

content.text:
1. In the Dashboard screen (first link in the left pane) click Edit profile (upper right). You can use the right arrows to change any values listed in the Details area:
    • Name
    • Display Name—Shown to your match persons
    • Identity—You, a child under 18, or someone else using this profile
    • Biological sex
    • Date of birth
    • Birthplace
  2. In the Permissions area, you can use the right arrows to change any of these values:
    • Manager—Invite another Living DNA user to co-manage your DNA profile. To do this, specify the user's email and click Save.
    • Research—Select whether to participate in Living DNA Global Research projects.
    • Matching—Opt in or out of Family Matching.
  3. To see additional profiles, if any, in the left pane click DNA Profiles. The DNA Profiles screen shows info for each profile. In this screen you can upload a DNA file, activate a DNA kit, download DNA data for the profile, or add a new profile.

1. To change your user settings, in the left pane click Account.
  2. In "Details" you can click the arrows and set your Name, Email address, and Password.
  3. In "Email settings" you can opt in or out of marketing programs.
  4. In "Your data privacy" you can learn how to permanently delete your account.
  5. You can also use the FAQ links at the bottom of the page.
